Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation2: The acquaintance passes another person in a quiet hallway.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s our ritual—me sitting on the edge of my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my mother’s gentle questions and my father’s quiet laughter. They expect these calls, and I know how much they mean to them. Tonight, as I walk down the nearly empty hallway at work, my phone buzzes. It’s my parents, right on time. I’m about to answer when I spot Jamie, an acquaintance from another department, coming toward me. We don’t know each other well, but there’s an unspoken rule to smile, maybe exchange a few words, to keep things friendly. My parents are waiting, but Jamie is almost here, and I can’t ignore them without seeming cold. My heart pounds as I weigh the warmth my parents expect against the easygoing friendliness Jamie expects. I feel caught, wishing I could split myself in two, but knowing I can’t.
